title: Belswan triumphant return to NPL after 26 years | Newcastle Herald
body_text:
Coach Mick Stafford was proud of how Belmont Swansea marked the club's return to Northern NSW top-flight football at Blacksmiths Oval on Thursday night after a 26-year absence.

But he said Belswans were not getting ahead of themselves following a spectacular, come-from-behind 5-2 win over Adamstown to launch their first NPL campaign.
The club is back in the top tier of Northern NSW football for the first time since 1999 after earning promotion as runaway Northern League One premiers.
Stafford knows the step up is enormous.
"I thought we represented ourselves and the area quite well," Stafford told the Newcastle Herald on Friday.
"We started really nervous. Adamstown were very aggressive and deserved to lead, but I think as the game went on we showed what we're all about, and we showed some resilience to come back from being behind twice to run away with it in the end.
"It's definitely step-by-step. We're not getting ahead of ourselves after winning one game, but it gives you a little bit of confidence to portray a better value of your team when you've got a bit of confidence behind you.
"We just want to continue that team spirit and that community spirit which I think was huge last night, sort of got us over the line with the crowd."
Captain Dino Fajkovic twice put Adamstown in front, first in the 10th minute then again in the 65th.
Ethan Hall equalised for the hosts four minutes before half-time then Reece Newton produced a spectacular, long-range, left-footed half-volley to level at 2-2 in the 75th minute.
Three minutes later, Belswans hit the lead when Adamstown conceded an own goal under attacking pressure. Kane Woolston, last year's Northern League One leading scorer, made it 4-2 in stoppage time before Newton iced the first-up win from the penalty spot.
"We were a bit rusty with patterns of passing, but I think [the performance] showed we were fit," Stafford said.
"We've got a certain style of play, and I think it was clear to see in the last 25 minutes what we can do.
"But we're not getting carried away. We'll move on to Edgeworth heaps quick. All of those top teams are another level above, so we've just got to stay humble and get back to our place and just work."
A large and loud Belswans crowd were out in force on Thursday night for the opening match of the 2025 NPL season.
It was standing room only in the sheds post-match as the club's victory song rang out.
"A lot of old boys, old past players and captains were in there and all the young, local JDL players and everyone was pretty excited and enjoyed the song and had a bit of hope about the future," Stafford said.
"It's pretty historic to win our first game in NPL, but we just want to put that behind us now.
"It's just going to get tougher and tougher and tougher."
Defending premiers and champions Broadmeadow were set to face off against Edgeworth in a grand final rematch at Jack McLaughlan Oval as the round continued on Friday night.
There is plenty of hype around Old Boys Day at Newcastle Olympic on Saturday (6.30pm), when Roy O'Donovan leads the line against Cooks Hill at Darling Street Oval.
Also on Saturday (4.30pm), Valentine travel to Maitland. On Sunday, Charlestown are at home to Westson at 4.30pm and Lambton play New Lambton at Arthur Edden Oval at 6.30pm.
NPL Women kicks off on Saturday with the Golden Eagles hosting defending champions Charlestown at Alder Park (6pm). On Sunday, newcomers Lake Macquarie City face a tough first-up test in last year's premiers Maitland at Cooks Square Park (4pm) and Olympic are away to Magic at 6pm.
